awd_titl_txt: Supporting Student Planning with Open Learner Models in Middle Grades Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is supported by the Education and Human Resources Core Research (ECR) program, which supports fundamental research in STEM learning and learning environments.  Self-regulated learning requires learners to set learning goals, plan how to achieve them, monitor the success of their plans, and make needed changes.  Critical gaps exist in our understanding of how and to what extent middle school students can engage in self-regulated learning during science inquiry activities.  Analogous gaps exist in our understanding of how to help students become self-regulated learners.  Computer-based learning tools might help fill these gaps, but these tools are usually "closed," meaning that how the software interprets students' knowledge and progress is hidden from the student.  In contrast, "open" learning tools provide students with understandable, visual representations of their knowledge and progress.  Such "open learner models" may be useful for helping students develop self-regulated learning skills.  For example, by providing easy-to-understand representations of student progress, open learner models may support the self-regulated learning processes of goal setting and planning. This project focuses on the design, development, and investigation of open learner models for student goal setting and planning in middle school science. The project will explore how students engage in goal-directed learning behaviors using data from eye tracking, log files, and think-aloud exercises.   It is anticipated that the project results can advance the goal of high quality STEM learning experiences for all students.
 
A major project goal is improving students' problem-solving abilities and learning outcomes through a theoretically grounded, data-driven open learner model. The project is designed to integrate an open learner model into the Future Worlds science learning environment for middle school ecosystems education. A culminating between-subjects experiment will be conducted to compare a baseline version of Future Worlds that does not have an open learner model (control condition) with a version of Future Worlds that has an embedded open learner model (experimental condition). The project will use state-of-the-art artificial intelligence computational frameworks to recognize students' goals and plans from observations of their problem-solving activities in an online learning environment.  It is hypothesized that the open learner model will yield better student learning outcomes, with improved science problem-solving skills, increased science content knowledge, increased metacognitive awareness, and enhanced science self-efficacy.  The project is designed to make significant contributions to both theory and practice of self-regulated learning. The project's aim is to make contributions to foundational knowledge and theory by advancing our understanding of how to improve science learning with open learner models: (1) With a focus on student goal setting and planning in technology-rich learning environments, the project aims to formulate an empirically-based theoretical framework for open learner model-enhanced learning that addresses both cognitive and metacognitive components of middle grades science education. (2) By conceptualizing goal setting and planning to account for self-regulated learning in the context of science problem solving, the project is designed to create a rich framework that connects goal setting and planning to students' problem solving and metacognitive processes. (3) By expanding to fine-grained process data, the project is intended to make methodological contributions that will enable the field to go beyond self-report measures, which have long dominated research on self-regulated learning. (4) The project plans to produce learning analytic techniques that yield predictive models of goal setting and planning in science problem solving, as well as open learner models to effectively support student goal setting and problem solving.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Self-regulated learning plays a key role in science education. Goal-driven problem solving is central to self-regulated learning, but there are critical gaps in our understanding of student goal setting and planning during science inquiry activities. By providing students with easy-to-understand visual representations of their problem solving activities, open learner models can support the self-regulated learning processes of goal setting and planning. This project focused on the design, development, and investigation of open learner models for student goal setting and planning in middle school science. The project explored how students engage in goal-directed learning behaviors using data from their problem-solving interactions in inquiry-based science learning environments. The project had three major objectives.

 1. Engage students in goal setting and planning during a series of classroom studies with a middle grades science learning environment. During students' problem-solving episodes in the learning environment, students used a planning tool that enabled them to easily specify and visualize their goals and plans. We explored how students engaged in goal-directed learning behaviors with a focus on investigating the temporal dynamics of student goal setting and planning using process data including log files and think-alouds. We also collected self-reports (metacognitive awareness, interest, motivation) and overall learning outcomes (science problem-solving skills, science content knowledge). We used this data to model and understand student goal setting and planning processes. 

 2. Devise open learner models of student goal setting and planning during science inquiry using state-of-the-art AI computational frameworks for plan, activity, and intent recognition. To create models that can be used to automatically recognize students' goals and plans from observations of their problem-solving activities in the learning environment, we used machine learning to create goal recognition models and plan recognition models. We created models using deep-learning-based machine learning frameworks to devise empirically-based models of student goal setting and planning.

3. Improve student science problem solving and learning outcomes through a theoretically grounded, data-driven open learner model. We investigated student goal setting and planning and their interaction with science problem solving and learning outcomes. We conducted a study of students using the planning tool and found that student usage of the tool aided in their explicit activation of planning and goal setting processes, which resulted in improved problem-solving outcomes for students who had a greater number of interactions with the planning tool.

This project has made significant contributions to our understanding of how to capture and analyze students' goal setting and planning behaviors during science problem solving. First, the project formulated an empirically-based framework for analyzing students' externalized goals and plans in the context of their inquiry-based learning behaviors during problem solving in a science learning environment. By analyzing the specific goals and plans that students set for themselves during problem solving in the broader context of scientific inquiry learning, this work established an analysis approach that can be consistently applied across diverse learning settings. Second, the project has produced a machine learning framework that leverages large language models to predict students' goals and plans based on observations of their actions in a science learning environment. This framework has yielded advances in AI capabilities in goal and plan recognition. Third, the project has introduced a large language model-based framework for automatically constructing planned sequences of actions for particular problem-solving goals. This framework enables the creation of open learner models that elaborate student goals and plans to support students as they engage in self-regulated learning processes during science problem solving. Fourth, the project has identified design principles for eliciting externalizations of students' goals and plans during science problem solving. These design principles can inform the design of learning environments that enable students to externalize their goal setting and planning behaviors during science problem solving. Fifth, the project has produced an implementation of a visual planning tool that has been iteratively refined and evaluated in two science learning environments. Finally, the project has produced a refined version of the Future Worlds learning environment with an integrated planning tool, as well as authoring tools that support the creation of new curricular content in Future Worlds. This enhanced version of Future Worlds will be shared with the research community and with middle school teachers and students.
